issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) requires a method named checkOrderReady() on SealSaloon and explicitly instructs orderMeal() to call checkOrderReady(). The reference solution instead implements a method named processOrders() (and orderMeal() calls processOrders()). This name/signature mismatch between the specification and the solution (absence of checkOrderReady()) is a structural inconsistency that can confuse students about the required API and the exact method they must implement/call.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution and template match the specification: provide a method named checkOrderReady() with the described behavior. Either rename processOrders() to checkOrderReady(), or add a public checkOrderReady() method that delegates to processOrders() and ensure orderMeal() calls checkOrderReady(). This keeps the API consistent with the UML and problem description and avoids confusing students about which method they must implement/call.

issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires a SealSaloon method named checkOrderReady() (used and described in the UML and in the ordering logic). In the solution repository the same functionality is implemented under the name processOrders() in SealSaloon.java. This is a same-concept/name mismatch: students reading the problem will search for or implement checkOrderReady(), but the reference implementation (and potentially tests) uses processOrders(), creating an unnecessary mapping burden and potential confusion about the required method name.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a consistent name across artifacts. Rename processOrders() in the solution to checkOrderReady(), or add a small wrapper method checkOrderReady() that delegates to processOrders(), and ensure orderMeal() calls checkOrderReady() as specified in the problem statement. Update any tests or documentation accordingly so all artifacts use the same identifier.
